--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> 
> >
> >This sounds like a good idea.  I will keep it in mind.  You know, 
> >ultimately what we are up against is just the fact that no sample 
> >can be guaranteed to perfectly represent its generating 
distribution.
> >It's likely there will always be extraordinary situations that 
were 
> >not encountered in whatever training set was experienced during 
> >evolution.  At the same time, that doesn't mean we can't do 
better, 
> >it just means reaching exactly 100% of all possible test cases is 
> >unlikely for complicated problems or domains.
> >
> >  
> >
> What has been surprising to me is how this problem has come up 
while 
> evolving for relatively simple problems, e.g. with prey capture 
the 
> difficulty level is increased by allowing the prey more 'head 
start' 
> moves before the agent can move. At below 4 moves the prey should 
always 
> remain within the agent's sensor range, thus a very simple 
solution is 
> possible whereby sensors are directly connected to motor outputs. 
And 
> yet the pass rate is still not 100% in all but the easiest 
problem, take 
> a look at these success rates for champs at each difficultly level:
> 
> Initial moves   100 tests   1000 tests
> -------------------------------------
> 0                     100%         100%
> 1                     96.48%      99.9%
> 2                     94.56%      99.9%
> 3                     95.10%      99.9%
> 
> 
> Hopefully that table didn't get too mangled in transmission.
> 
> So there is a balance between the sample size (and therefore 
search 
> speed) and solution quality, and for all but the most trivial 
problems 
> this balance seems to follow the law of dimishing returns. 
Hopefuly by 
> using a buffer of failed tests I can tip the balance more in our 
favour 
> - better solutions without all of the cost of performing 1000 
tests.
> 
> But yes I'm beginning to see that obtaining 100% perfect solutions 
for 
> most problems is perhaps unrealistic, but a 99.9% sucess is a lot 
more 
> useful that 95% - that could be the difference between a 
commercially 
> viable technique (say fingerprint ID'ing) and one that isn't.
> 

Another factor is the kinds of sensors and outputs you use.  If you 
use absolute sensors and outputs, e.g. "look north, south, east, 
west" and "move north, south, east, or west," then there is a need 
to rediscover the same principle more than once: if something is 
perceived in a certain direction then move in that direction.  
Because this principle would need to be discovered for each 
available direction, there is more room for failure or subtle flaws 
in at least one of the directions.

On the other hand, if you use relative (i.e. egocentric) 
representations, principles generally only need be discovered once.  
For example, if something is in front of you, then move towards it.  
Otherwise, if something is at angle from your front (notice- 
relative), then turn until you point towards it.  These principles 
apply in any position, and therefore are likely to end up more 
accurate overall.

ken
